texts.shortText: Easily recognized by its much larger size than other regional cormorants and by the distinctive white throat and pinkish-white chest. Bill powerful, with hooked tip. Rest of body dark glossy brown to black. Feathers on back brown with black margins. Eyes green, legs and feet black.
Total length 90 cm, wingspan 150 cm mass about 2000 g, sexes look alike, but female slightly smaller than male.

Global: Widespread across southern half of Africa, both inland and along coasts.

Local/Regional: Whole region, along coast and inland across wetter southern and eastern parts.

Common and widespread in both salt and freshwater habitats and often seen in groups roosting on rocks, logs, etc., where may associate with other cormorants. Stands erect, drying, oiling and preening plumage, often spreading the wings to dry and to warm stomach contents. Regularly commutes up to 10 km between roosting and foraging sites.

Flies with neck outstretched and lands belly-first in water, often using depressed tail as a brake. Sits low in the water with only head, neck and upper back exposed and forages by diving and seizing prey underwater. Feeds on bouts, each comprising a series of short dives of about 30 seconds with brief rests between. Longer rest periods between foraging bouts.

Feeds on fish, which are grasped between the mandibles underwater, the hook on the upper mandible often puncturing the skin. Small prey may be swallowed underwater. Larger prey swallowed head first and can take fish up to 376 g. May also swallow stones to reduce buoyancy.

Colonial nester, often in association with other cormorants or pelicans. Coastal populations mostly nest on islands or cliffs, but also on man-made structures. Nest a flat platform male of sticks, seaweeds and sundry other debris and guarded to prevent theft of materials by other individuals. Nest year round in Western Cape, but peaking in September - December. Eggs 2-5, bluish-white with chalky white layer. Incubation 27-28 days and brooded by both parents with changeovers at least twice a day. Chicks fledge at 49-56 days.
Unmistakable due to white breast and much larger size than other cormorants.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robertâ€™s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 575).
